column2: Description
Description
Path to the folder, containing the *.raw or *.d measured spectras.
The Output-Folder, where to save the converted spectra.
Set additional parameters for the ThermoRawFileParser. See Reference for possible options. Some settings my interfere with already set parameters in this script.
Set the number of parallel conversions done at once.
column7: Nicht auf convert_mzml und nicht auf convert_thermo_raw_files

column2: Description
Path to the folder, containing the *.raw or *.d measured spectras.
The Output-Folder, where to save extracted headers from *.d or *.raw files

Headers to be extracted from RAW-files. These need to be added as additional parameters prefixed with -ehtp/thtp/lhtp (for extra/tune or log headers) followed by the header name as displays e.g. in FreeStyle. In the Example, two headers are extracted.
column4: “-elhtp ‘Ambient temp. (°C)’--ehtp ‘Ion Injection Time (ms)’ ” to extract Ambient temperature and Ion Injection time directl from raws
column6: See FreeStyle for all headers. Run this script once, to get a list of all available headers in the *.raw file. This will also display under which category which header falls into.

column2: Headers to be extracted from .d-files. These need to be added as additional parameters (similar as to RAW files). In Bruker-files, there is no distinction between header types and simply `-htp` followed by the header name to be extracted is sufficient.
column7: No print of all available headers

column4: “  -cn ‘BRUKER_Digitizer_CurrentTemp_pickle_zlib’ ” to name the column in the results table
column6: You can check the bruker files directly to see which headers are available. This can be done by opening the generated spectra files via SQLite. As an alternative, this script can be called, which will report all available headers, which could be used for extraction.

column2: Description
A path containing mzML files. Their filename MUST correspond with the mzTAB files. These could be generated by the `File Conversion` workflow.
A path containing the (by FDR) filtered mzTAB identification files. These names MUST correspond to the mzML files.
column3: <Path to folder already filtered mzTAB identification files >

column2: Additional parameters, which are directly passed to the FeatureFinderMultiplex by OpenMS. See reference, for the parameters which could be set.

This can be used to set the resolution for the FeatureFinderCentroided of OpenMS. This can also be used to set additional parameters to influence the featuer search. See Reference for a full list of possible parameters
Charges for the feature finder to use to extract features.
column4: 1 (to also search for singly charged features
column7: Not used only in featurefinder centroided

column2: Charges for the feature finder to use to extract features.
column4: 10 (discard all features with a charge higher then 10
column7: Not used only in featurefinder centroided

column2: Additional parameters, directly passed to the Dinosaur JAR. In the reference a list of possible parameters can be found.
The Output-Folder, where to save the resulting features and statistics.
column3: <Output folder for the statistics and found features>

column2: Set the number of processes to be used in the FeatureFinderMultiplex
column7: Nur ein Fork, aber x viele Prozesse?

column2: Description
A path to the mzML files. These must be peak picked. These could be generated by the `File Conversion` workflow.
The Output-Folder, where to save generated mzML statistics.
column3: <Output folder for generated mzML statistics from this workflow>

column2: Description
The path to peak picked mzML files for the Comet-Search-Engine to do identification
The path to a FASTA-file.
Path to the Comet-Parameter Settings file. This should contain the needed Search Parameters, such as variable and fixed modifications

Internal identification parameter for Comet, to know if a decoy database should be generated. If set to 1 a decoy database is generated. If 0, a database containing decoys with the prefix “_DECOY” should be provided. This Parameter overwrites the comet-parameters setting “decoy_search”
The Output-Folder, where to save the  identification results from Comet
column3: <Output folder for identified Spectra and Statistics>

column2: Number of processes to be used to search one mzML-file.
Description
A path containing the idXML identification files. The identification results should be unfiltered and should contain decoys
The Output-Folder, saving the filtered identifications. Here, mzTAB-files are saved.
A parameter, to let the JVM know, how much memory it can allocate. Depending on the identifications, this parameter  may need to be increased
A parameter file to configure Pia. IMPORTANT: Pia needs to output mzTAB-files for filtered-PSMs in order for further steps to work properly. See reference for possible parameters
column7: Hier wird auch die FDR gesetzt!

column2: Description
Path to the folder, containing the *.raw or *.d measured spectras.
A path containing the (by FDR) filtered mzTAB identification files. These names MUST correspond to the RAW-Spectta files.
column3: <Path to folder already filtered mzTAB identification files >

column2: A path to a file which should contain: “accession”. “sequence”, “mz” and “RT” as columns. This CSV-file is used to directly extract XICs from the raw-spectra. Additionally, if aidentification matches with any of the defined accessions, also xics with the experimentally measured mz and RT is extracted.
column3: <Path to CSV-file having accession,sequence,mz,RT as columns>

column2: Output folder of the extracted ion chromatograms (+ some statistical information)
column3: <Output folder for the retrieved SpikeIns statistics)

column2: This sets the number of parallel XIC-Extractions via TRFP orAlphaTIMS at once. You can limit the number if too many are extracted at once and the machine is running out of memory.
